children.subject: And it isn't entirely crucial to get straight A's in important classes either. Of course, this does help, but showing serious interest in the area of research is often more important.

I don't know about others' experiences, but from my own it feels like the idea that you need A+'s to get good research opportunities is kind of inaccurate. Plenty of great labs only expect GPAs of 3.8+.

history.content: Currently 170 TA and researching in theory, I'd say you still have a good chance to boost up your grade in 170 as the final and project will make up a significantly large chunk. As for research in theory, I don't want to be discouraging but there is still a long way before you can even get started after 170. A plausible next step for you would be to take some theory courses 172/174/271/PCP next semester to get a taste of theory, and also you can check out this student group if you're interested in theory https://ugtcs.github.io/index.html.

Currently 170 TA and researching in theory, I'd say you still have a good chance to boost up your grade in 170 as the final and project will make up a significantly large chunk. As for research in theory, I don't want to be discouraging but there is still a long way before you can get started even after 170. A plausible next step for you would be to take some theory courses 172/174/271/PCP next semester to get a taste of theory, and also you can check out this student group if you're interested in theory https://ugtcs.github.io/index.html.

I'm pretty interested in doing some research during my undergraduate in theory/algorithms, and I'm currently taking CS170.

I work really hard on this class and I did pretty good for the first midterm. But for the second one, I made so many silly mistakes and couldn't make it to the 1 SD above average. If I kept doing this on the final, I might ended up with A-.

A- is perfectly fine for me in general, and I don't usually put attention on the course grade that much. But from what I know, undergraduates around me who are doing research in some particular area usually get an A+ (or at least a straight A) from the crucial classes of that area. 170 is THE class that concerning algorithms, and I'm feeling stressed out now for not getting a competitive enough grade for this class. 

So in general, how much weight does professor put on the grade of the crucial course grade when they consider admitting student for doing research? Currently I don't have any internship or research experience... what kind of project/experience can be helpful to get myself a good research opportunity?
history.subject: The Relationship between Course Grades and Research Opportunity
